text: the swing state of swing states a
bellwether for presidential elections
Ohio is the indispensable centerpiece of
nearly every winning scenario for both
Governor Romney and President Obama as
this map of electoral precincts shows
the president won here in 2008 with big
margins in the cities especially among
african-americans who were highly
motivated and enthusiastic and that's
the calculus that Democrats still need
to counteract the tide that George Bush
rode to win Ohio in the presidency in
2004 heavy Republican turnout in rural
areas in the West and in the suburbs
especially around Cincinnati to repeat
mr. Bush's accomplishment mr. Romney
needs all those votes and a good share
of working-class whites as well the
difficulty in that Ohio's economy is
mending and unemployment is down mr.
Romney opposed the bailout of automakers
and now the lowest unemployment rates
are in the Crescent from Cleveland to
Toledo to Cincinnati home to dozens of
automobile manufacturing plants and
suppliers both candidates have spent
millions on tough negative advertising
and traveled here often in the last few
days of the campaign the Republicans
focused on suburbs talk about economic
opportunity and jobs lost to China mr.
Romney and running mate Paul Ryan have
also targeted ads to reach coal industry
workers in the southeast mr. Obama and
Vice President Biden have covered the
state promoting the recovery and
painting mr. Romney is out of touch with
Ohioans ultimately the race could come
down to who mobilizes more voters mr.
Obama is clearly well organized on the
ground with more than twice as many
field offices by early September polls
showed his workers had reached more
voters than mr. Romney's had but in the
last two weeks the polls say Republicans
have caught up Democrats have been busy
registering new voters another key
barometer of the ground game more than
40% of
signed up since September 1st are in
Toledo and Cleveland and many of those
in black precincts college towns have
seen a 25% increase in Republican
precincts registration is also up
although modestly but those voters tend
to be much more likely to vote whether
mr. Obama can get newly registered young
and black voters to the polls a
notoriously difficult prospect could
decide Ohio and the election
you
